dt: {bc}to be away from school without permission

dt.t: Out on the playground, a boy from another homeroom cavorted around on a dirt bike, doing wheelies. He was {wi}playing hooky{/wi}, but evidently couldn't stay away.

When he was a small child [Babe] Ruth was a holy terror. He had incredible energy, was relentlessly active and was always in trouble. He {wi}played hooky{/wi} from school. He stole fruits and vegetables from stores, threw them at truck-drivers and ran and hid from the police.

He [Tom Sawyer] moped to school gloomy and sad, and took his flogging, along with Joe Harper, for {wi}playing hookey{/wi} the day before, with the air of one whose heart was busy with heavier woes and wholly dead to trifles.

dt: {bc}to be away from work or similar duties in a way likened to a child skipping school

dt.t: Hawkins is a tanned, muscular man in his 40s who's {wi}playing hooky{/wi} today from his job as a printer's ink chemist.

Most New Yorkers were at work last Tuesday while the official ceremony was going on—and many of those who {wi}played hooky{/wi} chose to go to the ticker-tape parade for the world champion New York Mets.
… in 1948 I once {wi}played hookey{/wi} from my radio writing job with Edgar Bergen to play in the Santa Monica Open.

et: probably from slang {it}hook, hook it{/it} to make off

dt: {bc}to perform a playback of (a usually recently recorded disc or tape)

to attach little importance to : minimize

dt: {bc}to serve as a {d_link|host|host:1} for (someone or something)

dt.t: Each year, the city {wi}plays host to{/wi} the film festival for one week.
As travel to the Third World has expanded, so, too, has concern about the damage wrought by mass tourism on the people and places that {wi}play host to{/wi} wandering North Americans and Europeans.
St. John's meets No. 3-ranked Duke and the Big East rival Miami on the road, and will {wi}play host to{/wi} No. 4 Syracuse, No. 13 Connecticut and surging Seton Hall at the Garden.
The grasslands {wi}play host to{/wi} {gloss}=provide a home for{/gloss} long-billed curlews and sage grouse, and eagles, osprey and coyotes scavenge the area.

shortdef: to serve as a host for (someone or something)
